newsitem.title: NEW ZEALAND: DB SEES FALL IN BEER SALES SLOWING DOWN.
newsitem.headline: DB SEES FALL IN BEER SALES SLOWING DOWN.

text.p: DB Group Ltd said on Wednesday it saw the ongoing decline in beer sales slowing later this year.
The brewer earlier reported a NZ$17.2 million first half profit against $16.0 million a year earlier. Market expectations were for net profit of around $15-16 million.
DB said first half Heineken sales had outstripped optimistic forecasts.
DB said the New Zealand market would continue to be highly competitive for all products in its beer, wine and spirit brand portfolios.
"The ongoing decline of the beer market is expected to slow down in the later part of the year," it said in a commentary.
While spirits and liqueur volumes were starting to reduce, this was being offset by what the company called "huge growth" in its ready-to-drink range.
In the wine market DB said it was expected that an ongoing market shift from casks (boxes) to bottles would continue.

"The directors have every confidence that the group will produce a satisfactory result for the full year based on the consistent implementation of brand-building policies in all its core markets," the statement added.
In its comment on Heineken, the company said first half sales had outstripped "the most optimistic forecast", but gave no more specific details.
DB Group is majority owned through a Heineken NV , Fraser and Neave Ltd joint venture.

The firm restructured its balance sheet in May, resulting in the cancellation of three out of four fully-paid shares, and analysts say one of the wider implications of the rejig will be to make the company a net payer of interest in the second half.
